vocabulary.definition: pain that won't go away
vocabulary.example: I can't sleep because my knees ache in the night.

vocabulary.definition: a body's abnormal reaction to certain foods or environmental substances (e.g. causes a rash)
vocabulary.example: Your son is extremely allergic to peanuts.

vocabulary.definition: emergency vehicle that rushes people to a hospital
vocabulary.example: We called the ambulance when Josh stopped breathing.

vocabulary.definition: a condition that causes people to lose their memory
vocabulary.example: I can't remember the accident because I had amnesia.

vocabulary.definition: medication that kills bacteria and cures infections
vocabulary.example: My throat infection went away after I started the antibiotics.

vocabulary.definition: a disease-causing organism
vocabulary.example: To prevent the spread of bacteria it is important that nurses wash their hands often.

vocabulary.definition: the rate at which blood flows through the body (high/low)
vocabulary.example: High blood pressure puts you at risk of having a heart attack.

vocabulary.definition: disease caused by the uncontrollable growth of cells
vocabulary.example: There are many different options when it comes to treating cancer.

vocabulary.definition: in need of water
vocabulary.example: It is easy for the elderly to become dehydrated in this heat.

vocabulary.definition: type of disease typically involving insulin deficiency
vocabulary.example: People with diabetes have to constantly check their blood sugar levels.

vocabulary.definition: a medical disorder that is harmful to a person's health
vocabulary.example: I understand that this disease runs in your family.

vocabulary.definition: many types of respiratory or intestinal infections passed on through a virus
vocabulary.example: People who have the flu should not visit hospital patients.

vocabulary.definition: instance in which blood stops pumping through the heart
vocabulary.example: People who smoke are at greater risk of having a heart attack.

vocabulary.definition: the virus that infects the human T-cells and leads to AIDS
vocabulary.example: HIV can be passed down from the mother to her fetus.

vocabulary.definition: general term for any condition that makes a person feel sick for a certain period of time
vocabulary.example: Her illness went away when she started eating better.

vocabulary.definition: an infant that is less than three months old
vocabulary.example: You have to support her neck because she is still a newborn.

vocabulary.definition: strong discomfort in certain areas of the body
vocabulary.example: We gave your husband some medicine to relieve some of the pain.

vocabulary.definition: a substance that is very dangerous if it enters the human body
vocabulary.example: The child was bitten by a poisonous snake.

vocabulary.definition: the uncontrollable tightening of a muscle
vocabulary.example: Ever since I injured my leg I've been having muscle spasms in my upper thigh.

vocabulary.definition: amount of heat measured in a body; higher than normal temperature
vocabulary.example: We brought Jesse to emergency because he was running a (high) temperature.

vocabulary.definition: treatment aimed at improving a person's mental or physical condition
vocabulary.example: I was able to go back to work a few weeks after starting the therapy.

vocabulary.definition: the thin tubes that transport blood around the body and back to the heart
vocabulary.example: I'm just looking for the best vein in which to insert the needle.

vocabulary.definition: a chair on wheels used for transporting patients from place to place
vocabulary.example: If you get in the wheelchair I'll take you down to see the garden.

vocabulary.definition: injury to body (“flesh wound” means not deep)
vocabulary.example: The wounded soldiers are being airlifted to the hospital.

vocabulary.definition: a photograph of a person's bones and organs
vocabulary.example: The technician took x-rays of my shoulder to make sure it wasn't broken.

vocabulary.definition: the regular pulse in music that dancers move to and audiences clap to
vocabulary.example: Dance music always has a strong beat.

vocabulary.definition: European orchestral and keyboard music that's written by composers
vocabulary.example: Sayoko loves listening to classical music, especially the music of Mozart and Beethoven.

vocabulary.definition: a genre of American music with origins in the rural folk music of Europe
vocabulary.example: Many people were surprised when Ray Charles began singing country music.

vocabulary.definition: traditional music from a particular region or country
vocabulary.example: Did you hear any traditional folk music while you were in China?

vocabulary.definition: a kind or style of music, movie, TV show, painting, etc.
vocabulary.example: In music classes at school, the only genres we studied were classical music and jazz.

vocabulary.definition: the combining of musical notes that sound good when played or sung together
vocabulary.example: If singers don't sing in harmony, it can sound terrible.

vocabulary.definition: a musical genre in which artists rap over beats and sampled sounds
vocabulary.example: When my girlfriend wants to listen to hip hop, she always puts on Jay-Z or Kanye West.

vocabulary.definition: a genre in which artists improvise within a rhythmic and harmonic framework
vocabulary.example: If you want to hear great jazz, listen to the recordings of John Coltrane and Miles Davis.

vocabulary.definition: the words of a song
vocabulary.example: If you don't listen to the lyrics, you won't know what a song is about.

vocabulary.definition: a tune, or the notes of a song
vocabulary.example: Can you whistle the melody of the song that begins with “Happy birthday to you”?

vocabulary.definition: a popular music genre with short, melodic songs that are easy to remember
vocabulary.example: My uncle's nearly 60, but he still likes listening to pop music.

vocabulary.definition: a pattern of beats and sounds that musicians play in time to and dancers move to
vocabulary.example: The rhythms of African music are much more complex than those of European music.

vocabulary.definition: rhythmic blues-based music played on guitar, bass, drums, etc.
vocabulary.example: Let's listen to some rock music for a change.

vocabulary.definition: music that developed over a very long time, like traditional African drumming and Chinese folk songs
vocabulary.example: People still play traditional music in Peru's mountain villages.

a level area for holding sports events, surrounded by seats for spectators
vocabulary.example: The arena was full of excited spectators cheering on their team.

vocabulary.definition: engaged in something, like playing sports, without payment; non-professional
vocabulary.example: The Olympic Games were originally for amateur athletes only.

vocabulary.definition: a person who trains for and competes in a sport
vocabulary.example: Most professional athletes spend hours every day in training.

vocabulary.definition: to give someone something as a reward for high achievement
vocabulary.example: All the members of the winning team were awarded a gold medal.

vocabulary.definition: to defeat someone in a game or a competition
vocabulary.example: Italy beat France to win the 2006 FIFA World Cup.

vocabulary.definition: a top-rated, highly successful player
vocabulary.example: The boxer Muhammad Ali was World Heavyweight Champion three times.

vocabulary.definition: a person who trains and directs an athlete or a sports team
vocabulary.example: Players should carry out their coach's instructions during a game.

vocabulary.definition: an organized event in which people compete to win
vocabulary.example: The English Premiership League is one of the world's top football competitions.

vocabulary.definition: a cup-shaped trophy, awarded as a prize in a contest
vocabulary.example: After they won the final game, the winners were awarded the Championship Cup.

vocabulary.definition: to win a victory over opponents in a game or contest; to beat
vocabulary.example: Our players were very happy after they defeated their opponents in the final game.

vocabulary.definition: the condition of being physically fit and healthy
vocabulary.example: I exercise at the gym every day for fitness and good health.

vocabulary.definition: a room or building equipped for physical exercise
vocabulary.example: Our gym has a lot of new exercise equipment, including running machines and cycling machines.

vocabulary.definition: a piece of engraved metal given to signify an achievement or an honor
vocabulary.example: Every athlete's dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympic Games.

vocabulary.definition: the number of points a competitor or team earns during a game
vocabulary.example: Do you know how to keep score in badminton?

vocabulary.definition: a sports arena with tiered seating for spectators
vocabulary.example: The stadium was built for sports, but it's sometimes used for concerts as well.

vocabulary.definition: a person who helps athletes develop their skills and fitness
vocabulary.example: Some players are a bit lazy and need a strict trainer to make them work hard.

vocabulary.definition: the act of winning a game or contest
vocabulary.example: The players had worked very hard, and they deserved their victory.

vocabulary.definition: an appliance that cools down the air in a home or building
vocabulary.example: The airconditioner keeps the office nice and comfortable even when it's very hot outside.

vocabulary.definition: a dangerous slide of snow down a mountain
vocabulary.example: The skiers were warned about a possible avalanche.

vocabulary.definition: temperature less than 0 degrees Celsius/(32F)
vocabulary.example: It's supposed to go below freezing before the weekend.

vocabulary.definition: a storm with lots of snow and wind
vocabulary.example: The airplane couldn't take-off because of the blizzard.

vocabulary.definition: common expression for describing a very hot day
vocabulary.example: It was boiling hot, so we all jumped into the lake.

vocabulary.definition: light wind
vocabulary.example: Don't bother with a hat. There is always a breeze near the ocean.

vocabulary.definition: water in the sky that appears as a white or grey mass
vocabulary.example: It may look cloudy in the morning, but the sun always comes out by afternoon.

vocabulary.definition: raining slightly
vocabulary.example: I think I'll take the dog for a walk. It's only drizzling now.

vocabulary.definition: thick water vapor that blocks one's vision
vocabulary.example: We couldn't see the bridge because there was too much fog.

vocabulary.definition: the expected weather for the future
vocabulary.example: According to the 5 day forecast, it's going to rain on our wedding day.

vocabulary.definition: extremely hot weather that is much higher than average
vocabulary.example: During the heat-wave we cooled our beds down with ice packs.

vocabulary.definition: a tropical storm with very strong wind and rain
vocabulary.example: Half of the buildings on the island were flattened by the hurricane.

vocabulary.definition: electrical discharge and flash between a cloud and the ground
vocabulary.example: The outdoor pool always closes when the lifeguards think lightning is coming.

vocabulary.definition: water that falls to earth
vocabulary.example: My hair is all wet and messy from the rain.

vocabulary.definition: a band of colours found in the sky after a rainfall
vocabulary.example: According to legend you can find a pot of gold at the end of a rainbow.

vocabulary.definition: heavy,dark cloud cover caused by pollution
vocabulary.example: You really notice the smog downtown in this type of humidity.

vocabulary.definition: frozen water that warms slightly as it falls to earth
vocabulary.example: It is already snowing up in the mountains, so the ski season should be great this year.

vocabulary.definition: the gassy star that warms the earth
vocabulary.example: We hope to have sunshine on the day of the beach picnic.

vocabulary.definition: how warm or cold the air is
vocabulary.example: how warm or cold the air is

vocabulary.definition: thunder is a loud noise after lightning, caused by rapid expansion of air superheated by the lightning
vocabulary.example: Let's close all of the windows. It looks like a thunderstorm is coming.

vocabulary.definition: blowing air outside
vocabulary.example: It's too windy to play golf today.

vocabulary.definition: the middle part of the day
vocabulary.example: I'll see you again tomorrow afternoon.

vocabulary.definition: the season between summer and winter
vocabulary.example: She went off to college in the autumn of 1999.

vocabulary.definition: a period of 100 years
vocabulary.example: It took more than a century to complete the cathedral.

vocabulary.definition: the time of day when sunlight first begins to appear
vocabulary.example: We danced till dawn.

vocabulary.definition: a period of 24 hours beginning at midnight : one of the seven time periods that make up a week
vocabulary.example: We're open seven days a week, 365 days a year.

vocabulary.definition: a period of 10 years
vocabulary.example: The war lasted nearly a decade.

vocabulary.definition: the last part of the day and early part of the night
vocabulary.example: We're going out to dinner this evening.

vocabulary.definition: the season between summer and winter
vocabulary.example: Fall is one of my favorite seasons, because all foliage changes colors to yellow, red, it's beautiful.

vocabulary.definition: one of the 24 equal parts of a day : 60 minutes
vocabulary.example: The job pays ten dollars an hour.

vocabulary.definition: the middle of the night : 12 o'clock at night
vocabulary.example: Her parents wanted her home before midnight.

vocabulary.definition: a unit of time equal to 60 seconds
vocabulary.example: Bake the cake for 25–30 minutes.

vocabulary.definition: a very short period of time
vocabulary.example: She stopped for a moment and peeked into the window.

vocabulary.definition: any one of the 12 parts into which the year is divided
vocabulary.example: July is my favorite month.

vocabulary.definition: the early part of the day : the time of day from sunrise until noon
vocabulary.example: On Sunday mornings I like to relax and read the newspaper.

vocabulary.definition: the time of darkness between one day and the next
vocabulary.example: Who are you calling at this time of night?

vocabulary.definition: the middle of the day : 12 o'clock in the daytime
vocabulary.example: Meet me at noon.

vocabulary.definition: a temporary stop
vocabulary.example: After a pause the teacher continued the lesson.

vocabulary.definition: a part or step in a process
vocabulary.example: The project will be done in three phases.

vocabulary.definition: a unit of time that is equal to ¹/₆₀ of a minute
vocabulary.example: There are 60 seconds in a minute.

vocabulary.definition: the season between winter and summer
vocabulary.example: We've had a rainy spring.

vocabulary.definition: the warmest season of the year that is after spring and before autumn
(on) the present day
vocabulary.example: What's the date today?

vocabulary.definition: (during) the night of the present day
vocabulary.example: Tonight will be my first chance to meet her.

vocabulary.definition: on the day after today
vocabulary.example: I'll see you tomorrow

vocabulary.definition: a period of seven days
vocabulary.example: I can meet you sometime next week.

vocabulary.definition: Saturday and Sunday
vocabulary.example: What are you doing this weekend?

vocabulary.definition: the coldest season of the year that is after autumn and before spring
vocabulary.example: They spend winters in Florida.

vocabulary.definition: a unit of time that is equal to 12 months or 365 or sometimes 366 days
vocabulary.example: I haven't seen her in a year.

vocabulary.definition: kills people for political reasons, or in return for payment
breaks in to buildings to steal
buys and sells illegal drugs
is a member of a violent criminal gang (group)
is a violent young troublemaker
takes people away by force and demands money to free them
deliberately kills another person
steals money etc, using force or the threat of force
secretly gets information about another country
uses violence for political reasons
steals property from other people (without using violence)
deliberately destroys or damages public property
a movie with many exciting and violent scenes
vocabulary.example: Our teenage boys love watching action movies.

vocabulary.definition: all the actors and actresses in a movie or TV show
vocabulary.example: It had a good cast, but the story wasn't very interesting.

vocabulary.definition: one of the people in a story
vocabulary.example: Harry likes movies with lots of interesting and unusual characters.

vocabulary.definition: a place where movies are shown on a big screen
vocabulary.example: Let's meet in front of the cinema just before the movie starts.

vocabulary.definition: a film with lots of funny scenes
vocabulary.example: Let's see a comedy and have a good laugh.

vocabulary.definition: the person in charge of making a movie
vocabulary.example: The director gets really angry when actors forget their lines.

vocabulary.definition: a film that's about real people, events or issues
vocabulary.example: How can you eat junk food after seeing that documentary Super Size Me?

vocabulary.definition: a movie about realistic characters in dramatic situations
vocabulary.example: Maria loves legal dramas with lots of courtroom scenes.

vocabulary.definition: a movie that frightens and shocks people
vocabulary.example: If you love horror movies, you've got to see Fright Night.

vocabulary.definition: the series of events that form the main story
vocabulary.example: It was a good film, but the plot was difficult to follow at times.

vocabulary.definition: a genre with stories set in the future or in outer space
vocabulary.example: Have you seen that sci-fi film Interstellar yet?

vocabulary.definition: a holiday where you purchase the travel and accommodation together
to travel or hike carrying one's belongings in a backpack
an extremely beautiful view
the activity of spending a holiday (vacation) living in a tent or campervan
a cheaper form of flying than a scheduled flight
the place at the airport where you register for your flight and deposit your luggage
where you wait for your flight to be called
somewhere a long way away
an organised group shown around a place of interest by an expert
a glossy publication with details of holiday packages
where you go for a holiday
a special holiday that you are unlikely to repeat
a place where lots of people go for a holiday
crowds of tourists
objects produced locally
an extended weekend holiday including Friday or Monday
outside of the main holiday period
the place where your passport is checked
very pretty village
sites of interest to tourists
a holiday where you supply your own food
a short holiday
extremely beautiful countryside

vocabulary.word: to get away from it all
vocabulary.definition: to get away from it all: to take a holiday to escape a busy or stressful lifestyle
to look around the tourist sites
somewhere where too many tourists go
a shop that specializes in booking holidays
the American term for 'holiday'.
a holiday, often in Africa, to observe wild animals
a cheap form of accommodation
the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe
vocabulary.example: I went outside to get some fresh air.

vocabulary.definition: a clear liquid, without colour or taste, that falls from the sky as rain and is necessary for animal and plant life
vocabulary.example: The human body is about 50 percent water.

vocabulary.definition: the surface of the earth that is not covered by water
vocabulary.example: It is cheaper to drill for oil on land than at sea.

vocabulary.definition: one of the seven large land masses on the earth's surface, surrounded, or mainly surrounded, by sea and usually consisting of various countries
vocabulary.example: Stanley traversed the African continent from west to east.

vocabulary.definition: a piece of land completely surrounded by water
vocabulary.example: They live on the large Japanese island of Hokkaido.

vocabulary.definition: a raised part of the earth's surface, much larger than a hill, the top of which might be covered in snow
vocabulary.example: The Matterhorn is one of the biggest mountains in Europe.

vocabulary.definition: a very large area of sea
vocabulary.example: These mysterious creatures live at the bottom of the ocean.

vocabulary.definition: the salty water that covers a large part of the surface of the earth, or a large area of salty water, smaller than an ocean, that is partly or completely surrounded by land
vocabulary.example: We went swimming in the sea.

vocabulary.definition: a large area of water surrounded by land and not connected to the sea except by rivers or streams
vocabulary.example: We used to go boating on that lake.

vocabulary.definition: a natural wide flow of fresh water across the land into the sea, a lake, or another river
vocabulary.example: We sailed slowly down the river.

vocabulary.definition: an area of land that has its own government, army, etc.
vocabulary.example: Sri Lanka is my native country, but I've been living in Belgium for the past five years.

vocabulary.definition: a self-contained program or piece of software; an application, especially when downloadable to a mobile device
a copy of files from a computer's hard disk, usually made on some external medium such as CD-ROM or flash drive
a bit is the smallest piece of information that computers use. For simplicity, a PC uses bits in groups of 8 called bytes (8 bits = 1 byte)
a program like Firefox or Internet Explorer. You use it to view or browse the Internet
a defect or fault in a program
a kind of memory used to make a computer work faster
the information (text, pictures, audio etc) that you create or share on a computer
a small program that tells a PC how a peripheral works
messages sent from one computer to another
a specific computer record. It could contain data such as text (e.g. essay.doc), or a program such as paint.exe
a sub-division of a computer's hard disk into which you put files
the main disk inside a computer used for storing programs and information
the image that you see on the screen is made of thousands of tiny dots, points or pixels
the number of dots or pixels per inch (sometimes per centimetre) used to create the screen image
a mobile phone that includes a palmtop computer or PDA and also gives access to Internet and email
a tablet computer; a mobile computer consisting of a screen only, and controlled by touching the screen
a small, unauthorized program that can damage a computer
someone whose job is to keep the financial records of a business or person
a person who acts in a play, movie, etc.
a person who designs buildings
a person who creates art
a person who owns a bank or who has an important job in a bank
a person or company that builds or repairs things
a man or woman who works in business
a professional cook who usually is in charge of a kitchen in a restaurant
a person whose job is to care for people's teeth
a person who plans how something new will look and be made
a person who is skilled in the science of medicine
vocabulary.example: He needed medicine but refused to go to a doctor.

vocabulary.definition: a person who studies or specializes in economics
vocabulary.example: Economists are predicting rapid inflation.

vocabulary.definition: a person who works on and repairs electrical equipment
a person who has scientific training and who designs and builds complicated products, machines, systems, or structures
vocabulary.example: Design engineers are working on ways to make the cars run more efficiently.

vocabulary.definition: food served before the main course
vocabulary.example: For our appetizers we'll have spring rolls and fish cakes, please.

vocabulary.definition: a nice smell, especially from food, wine, coffee, etc.
vocabulary.example: I love the aroma of freshly-baked bread.

vocabulary.definition: to cook in an oven
vocabulary.example: Have you ever tried baking a cake?

vocabulary.definition: having little taste; tasteless
vocabulary.example: Most people think British food is bland.

vocabulary.definition: one part of a meal
vocabulary.example: French meals usually have three courses; the hors d'oeuvre, the entrée and the dessert.

vocabulary.definition: a country or region's style of cooking
vocabulary.example: There's more to Italian cuisine than pizza and pasta.

vocabulary.definition: knives, forks, and spoons used for eating
vocabulary.example: We only use our best cutlery on special occasions.

vocabulary.definition: a food made from milk, like butter, cheese, yoghurt, etc.
vocabulary.example: Dairy products are becoming more popular in Asia.

vocabulary.definition: tasting very good
vocabulary.example: The food in this restaurant is really delicious.

vocabulary.definition: sweet food eaten at the end of a meal
vocabulary.example: Have you ever tried Middle-eastern desserts like baklava?

vocabulary.definition: all the foods a person or animal usually eats
vocabulary.example: My doctor said a vegetarian diet rich in protein is best.

vocabulary.definition: a deep plate for cooking or serving food
vocabulary.example: I baked the pie in a special pie dish.

vocabulary.definition: food prepared and cooked in a particular way
vocabulary.example: What's your favourite French dish?

vocabulary.definition: the main course of a meal
vocabulary.example: What did you order for your entrée?

vocabulary.definition: quickly served food like burgers, French fries, fried chicken, etc.
vocabulary.example: I only get fast food if I don't have time to cook.

vocabulary.definition: the taste of food or drink
vocabulary.example: Japanese people think how food looks is as important as the flavour.

vocabulary.definition: to cook something in hot oil or fat
vocabulary.example: Heat oil in a pan and fry the chopped onions for five minutes.

vocabulary.definition: seeds used as food like wheat, rice, lentils, etc.
vocabulary.example: Grains like wheat and rye are used to make different kinds of bread.

vocabulary.definition: to cook something just above or below a heat source
vocabulary.example: Grilling a fish is better than frying it.

vocabulary.definition: all the foods used to make a dish or meal
vocabulary.example: What ingredients do we need to make spaghetti sauce?

vocabulary.definition: foods and food products that are unhealthy because of all the fat, salt or sugar they contain
vocabulary.example: People who love junk food soon get fat and unhealthy.

vocabulary.definition: the list of foods and drinks served in a restaurant, café, pub, etc.
vocabulary.example: Let's check the menu before deciding whether to eat here.

vocabulary.definition: instructions for cooking a dish or a meal
vocabulary.example: My mum has a great recipe for chocolate pudding.

vocabulary.definition: anything from the sea that can be eaten
vocabulary.example: If you eat vegetarian food plus fish and seafood, but not meat or poultry, you're a pescatarian/pescetarian.

vocabulary.definition: tasting very good
vocabulary.example: Bob thinks Indian food is tastier than Chinese food.

parent of my parent

vocabulary.definition: child of my uncle or aunt

child of my child

vocabulary.example: Father-in-law / Mother in-law

vocabulary.definition: sibling of my spouse; spouse of my sibling

vocabulary.definition: spouse of my daughter/son
vocabulary.example: Son-in-law / Daughter-in-law

vocabulary.definition: my previous spouse (we divorced)
vocabulary.example: Ex-husband / Ex-wife

vocabulary.definition: my sibling born to my father or mother but not both
vocabulary.example: Half-brother / Half-sister

vocabulary.definition: new spouse of one of my parents
vocabulary.example: Step-father / Step-mother

vocabulary.definition: child of my spouse but not of me
vocabulary.example: Step-son / Step-daughter

vocabulary.definition: the joint where the foot joins the leg
either one of the two long body parts that join the top of your body at the shoulder and that end at the hand or wrist
the hair that grows on a man's cheeks and chin
the front part of the body between the neck and the stomach
either one of the two soft parts on a woman's chest that produce milk when she has a baby
the part of the face that is below the eye and to the side of the nose and mouth
the front part of the body between the neck and the stomach
the part of the face below the mouth and above the neck
the joint where your arm bends
the line of hair that grows over your eye
any one of the hairs that grow along the top of the eyelid
one of the five long parts of the hand that are used for holding things
the back part of your foot that is below the ankle
the joint that bends at the middle of your leg
one of the long body parts that are used especially for standing, walking, and running
either one of the two soft parts that surround the mouth
the opening through which food passes into the body
